title: Monday, 20th June, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Hi there

PM

Yeah, just about everything's up

PM

So let's get an image up

11:02 am
PM

PM

Ken Clarke

PM

Confirmed he's stepping down at the next election -- after 50 years in parliament

11:02 am
PM

Assuming the current Cameron term runs all the way

PM

But what's weird here is that Clarke shared his news through China Daily

PM

Yes, really

11:03 am
PM

The interview is here: http://usa.chinada...ntent_25753536.htm

PM

Andrew Moody(China Daily USA) got the scoop

PM

And he placed it roughly in the middle of his story

11:04 am
PM

He has been MP for Rushcliffe in Nottingham since 1970 and he revealed that he will be stepping down at the next general election, due to be held in 2020, after by then spending 50 years in the Commons.
"I have told the officers of my constituency association that once we have finished the boundary changes they had better start choosing my successor. I will not stand again. This is my last parliament."

PM

So, congrats to Ken Clarke. Quite an innings

11:05 am
PM

Footsie up 2.7%

BE

!

PM

I thought that, rather than clog this chat with Brexit grey

11:05 am
PM

PM

But then I realised we'd have pretty much nothing to talk about

PM

It's a problem

11:05 am

PM

PM

11:06 am

BE

Though anecdote isn't data.

ah, intersting

PM

(Sorry for spelling)

BE

Sterling's up, gilts down, FTSE up, grey's elsewhere.

11:09 am
PM

Here's the split of the papers..

PM

The following newspapers/weekly magazines have now come out in support of the remain campaign: The FT, The Times, The Observer, The Independent, The Mail on Sunday, The Mirror, People and The New Statesman.

The following newspapers/weekly magazines have now come out in support of the leave campaign: The Sun, The Sun on Sunday, The Sunday Times, The Sunday Telegraph, The Sunday Express and The Spectator.

PM

Daily Mail not in that list

11:09 am
PM

Which is from BNY

BE

Well, we know what side the Mail's on. It doesn't need pointed out.

BE

I think it's Chris Horrie's book on the Sun that details how it does elections

11:11 am
BE

Namely, it chooses what's likely to be the winning side. There's a Murdochian influence and so on and so forth, but really, its strategy is rarely more complicated than backing the winning team.

BE

Which, it seems, may not work this time.

PM

hmm

11:12 am

Still feels scary to me

PM

Despite 2.7% on the Footsie

PM

And sterling's moved 2 cents

11:12 am

Biggest move in cable since 2009 I think.

BE

BE

Feel free to go read that, as well as or perhaps instead of us.

11:13 am
undefined
BE

In terms of movers ........

PM

Guess we go straight from brexit to ....cats

11:13 am
BE

Circassia

BE

This is fascinating.

PM

Maximise clicks

11:14 am
PM

Circassia

PM

down 66% currently

PM

(We can't find the auto pricing code)

11:15 am
PM

Trial statement here: http://www.investe...1606200700076205B/

BE

(The redesigned FT site has hidden any way to get a share price extremely deeply. Someone might want to take a wee look at that.)

PM

TL;DR -- it seemed to work, but so too did that placebo

11:15 am
BE

Yeah, this is really odd.

BE

The drug worked. Fantastically well, in fact.

PM

Doesnt it just mean that cat allergies are largely a figment of people's imagination?

11:16 am
BE

No! No nnonononononononno no.

PM

(Yes, i know this is not true.)

PM

My youngest is allergic to our two cats; it causes some household tension.

11:16 am
BE

What we can say is that the drug works. Really well. 58.2% reduction.

BE

And so do sugar pills. 58.5% reduction.

BE

So, sugar pills work slightly better than the drug.

11:18 am
BE

This is ...... baffling. One assumes either the earlier stage trials were poorly designed or this one is.

BE

The company's response would seem to tilt suspicion to the former.

BE

As they've scrapped it.

11:19 am
BE

(@john.e: it's a cat allergy treatment being funded with shareholder money. There's lots and lots and lots of public money going into antibiotics, as there should be.)

BE

So while Cat-SPIRE's only about a quarter of Circassia's value, we're now revaluing the entire portfolio on the basis that it might not work either.

BE

Caz, I think, is shop here.

11:20 am
BE

This morning Circassia announced negative results from the Cat-Spire
PIII study, failing to show a benefit on cat allergy symptoms vs. placebo,
with a far higher than expected placebo effect. In light of these results we
expect the rest of the allergy program to be discontinued. We also expect a
corresponding cut on allergy OpEx, and a refocus on the two assets acquired
last year, Aerocrine Asthma diagnostics and Prosonix generic respiratory
drugs. Removing the allergy program, our NPV is lowered c.60% to 170p,
the basis for our new 170p PT, c.35% downside. Shares could undershoot
our new NPV today, with the market potentially seeing a floor at 125p (c55%
downside), which would equate to Aerocrine and Prosonix 2015 acquisition
prices (£139m/£100m), plus cash (£139m). Investors could alternatively give
credit for the respective strong growth of Aerocrine since being acquired, and
the subsequent UK approval achieved by Prosonix, which could justify a 15%
premium to the acquisition prices, getting to 150p per share, c.45% downside.

BE

Cat-Spire PIII results showed a surprisingly strong placebo effect,
with no placebo adjusted benefit for Spire therapy. On the first of the
two co-primary endpoints, for TRSS symptom score, for the 4x6nmol
regimen there was a 58.2% improvement, with a 59.8% improvement for
8x6nmol, and 58.5% improvement for placebo. For the other co-primary
of rescue medication use, 4x6nmol had a 5.7 point decrease, 8x6nml had
a 5.5 point decrease, and placebo had a 5.9 point decrease.

BE

.... written pre call, which has already happened.

11:21 am
BE

On the call today, details tbd, we expect the company
to indicate that they will now minimise further investment in the allergy
program, refocusing on Aerocrine and Prosonix. We will be interested in the
extent to which cost can be taken out/avoided. Slightly further out, by H1’16
results in late July, we expect the company to elaborate on their intended use
of cash, including whether there are further internal projects that will be
pursued, or whether the company could look to conduct in-licensing.

BE

Forecast changes. We remove the Allergy program from our model, and
include cost savings. With significantly lower near-term costs, our near-term
loss per share is reduced, and we continue to forecast profitability by 2020,
however our long-term earnings power is significantly reduced.

BE

And Stifel.

11:22 am
BE

Top-line results from cat allergy immunotherapy study – primary
endpoint not achieved. The study compared a four-dose course of Fel d 1
allergen peptides, two sequential courses (eight doses) and placebo. The
primary endpoint was the mean combined score of total rhinoconjunctivitis
symptom score (TRSS) and rescue medication score. All groups had a greatly
improved combined score versus baseline, with an indistinguishable difference
in response from the placebo and treatment groups: 4x6nmol reduction =
58.2%, 8x6nmol reduction = 59.8%, placebo reduction = 58.5%.
Next steps: review data and wider implications. Circassia will review the
full dataset to see if there were any other confounding factors, and wider
implications for its allergy portfolio. As such, the company will stop the recently
initiated grass allergy pivotal study, and prep work on its dose-ranging study
with ragweed allergy therapy. The phase IIb study of its house dust mite
allergy product is well advanced so Circassia is assessing the implications
associated with continuing the trial. The birch allergy therapy is nearing
completion in a phase II study which will continue as planned. The company
will continue to focus on sales growth in its NIOX asthma management
franchise, and establish its specialty commercial infrastructure in the US and
Europe.
Effect on valuation: The Phase III Cat-SPIRE programme represented 22%
(94p) of our 448p NPV for the company, with the remaining programmes for
Grass, House Dust Mite and Ragweed making up 44% of the total NPV.

BE

We should note that Woodford's in this.

BE

19.2%

11:22 am
PM

Ouch

BE

He is also somewhat responsible for Investec having 57.6%.

BE

Plus he's in Imperial Innovations.

11:23 am
BE

Circassia being Imperial's biggest investment.

Woodford Patient Capital Trust PLC (WPCT:LSE): Last: 90.29, up 0.238 (+0.26%), High: 90.65, Low: 88.50, Volume: 1.83m
BE

(@Mouselet: because that's not how PHIII trials work.)

11:24 am
BE

Impact on Imperial's about 7% off NAV. Not that anyone seems to care today.

Imperial Innovations Group PLC (IVO:LSE): Last: 425.00, down 10.13 (-2.33%), High: 436.75, Low: 412.00, Volume: 65.13k
BE

Exactly 7%, in fact. According to caz. That was my guess.

11:25 am
PM

heh

BE

On the back of this morning’s Circassia trial results, we lowered our
Circassia PT from 410p to 170p, removing all value for the allergy
program. Today we also lower the value we ascribe to Imperial’s 9.3%
Circassia stake from £78m to £36m, which trims our Imperial NAV
valuation from £898m to £830m. Today we cut our Imperial PT by 7%,
from 566p to 524p. The magnitude of our Imperial PT downgrade is
smaller than that for Circassia, firstly because Circassia only accounted for
15% of our Imperial NAV, secondly also because in our Imperial NAV we
valued Circassia at the current market valuation, rather using our more
bullish NPV as was the case for our value of Circassia standalone.

BE

Circassia Phase III Allergy result is disappointing, however we don’t
see read-through to the rest of IVO's portfolio. Circassia has been IVO’s
most high profile asset, with the biggest single NAV contribution, however
the importance of Circassia to IVO’s NAV has been falling, with IVO not
participating in the Circassia equity raise used to fund the Aerocrine and
Prosonix acquisitions, and IVO having raised further equity.

11:26 am
BE

We see a number of other healthcare portfolio catalysts: (1.) Cellmedica
updates, including Phase II data for their T-cell immunotherapy in H1’17, as
well as potential further disclosure on the Baylor college immuno-oncology
deal announced last week. We also await early data from (2.) PsiOxus
(cancer vaccines) and (3.) Cresendo (Oncology antibodies). As well as trial
read-outs, we could also see partnering announcements.

BE

(@Mouselet: I was under the impression that the FDA don't much like equivalence trials in isolation. Not an expert though so am prepared to be wrong.)

11:28 am

Italian PR choosing London for capital formation purposes.

PM

SEC S.p.A., the largest independent advocacy, public relations and integrated communications agency in the Italian market, today announces its intention to apply for admission to trading on AIM, ("Admission") to raise between €4 -6 million. UBS is acting as the Company's Financial Advisor, WH Ireland as Nominated Adviser and Broker. NCTM (Italy), Gowling WLG and Hill Dickinson (UK) as legal advisers to the Company.

PM

Founded in 1989 by current Chairman Fiorenzo Tagliabue, the Group has grown both organically and through acquisition. It has acquired a number of majority stakes in companies, with operations in Italy, Belgium, Germany and Spain. The Company's activities comprise public relations, advocacy and integrated services and support over 500 clients in its various operations.

Revenue for 2015 was over €21 million with an EBITDA of €3.4 million, representing CAGR at 44% over the last two years.

undefined
BE

What do we have in the way of fantasy M&A?

11:32 am
BE

Numis have done the numbers on Aberdeen.

BE

Over which there's some disagreement about whether or not it's for sale.

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
BE

See passim for that. Numis reckon a 40% premium's possible.

BE

We conclude that an acquirer
would need to be fairly large (probably a global top 40 asset manager to have at
least equal scale with Aberdeen and allow scope for reasonable cost synergies),
have willingness to acquire access to capital (ruling out some of the bank owned
asset managers), have some similarity in investment approach business model /
culture and would probably lack a significant EM/Asia franchise but would want
one (Aberdeen's key strategic asset that most companies would want exposure to
long term in our view). Whilst a PE deal is possible, given the lower scope for cost
synergies and lesser desire to own an EM franchise long term, we see these as less
likely participants. We believe a realistic take out value would be around £5.0bn /
380p per share (c.40% above the current market value).

BE

Possible buyers? Uh, everyone.

11:34 am
BE

Blackrock, JP Morgan, Capital, PIMCO, Amundi, Natixis,
Invesco, T. Rowe, Legg Mason, AMG, Sumitomo Mitsui, Ameriprise, AllianceBernstein,
Standard Life, Pru/M&G, Credit Suisse, Mitsubishi, Macquarie and Aviva.

BE

SOTP ............

BE

We believe a realistic take out value could be around £5.0bn/380p
per share (c.40% above the current market value), valuing the EM/Asia franchise at
£2.7bn (14x EBIT contribution), decaying franchises (Global Equity/Quant/Cash) at
£0.6bn (8x), other franchises at £2.7bn (12x), recurring non-direct costs less assumed
deal cost synergies of £100m at -£0.8bn (12x) and re-financing non core equity capital
instruments net of surplus capital of -£0.2bn.

11:35 am
BE

(@Pseudonym: what you're referring to would seem to be a placebo kebab.)

BE

They remain on hold.

BE

● Investment Case: Short term, it remains very much exposed to the fortunes of EM,
where for choice we would prefer to wait for a more attractive entry point. Long term,
you need to believe the group can achieve growth in other areas and/or make further
cost cutting motivated acquisitions and/or will be bid for, to justify purchasing today

11:36 am
BE

undefined
PM

Quick bit of strategy

11:40 am
PM

Andrew Lapthorne at Soc Gen trying to remind everyone that -- post the referendum vote -- it's still nuts out there

PM

Global equity markets continued to struggle last week, with the MSCI World index off 1.8%
pushing the index back into red for the year. Big losses were seen in Japan with the Topix 500
down 6% and the volatile Mothers index crashing 18.5% over the week as the yen continued to
strengthen. According to the BOE measure, the trade-weighted yen is now up more than 20%
over the past year and back to where it stood three years ago. In the battle for the weakest
currency, Japan looks to have thrown in the towel.

PM

Sorry for the formatting

11:40 am
PM

Whatever the outcome of the Brexit vote this week investors will still be facing the prospect of
negative rates and negative yields on a huge range of bonds, massive corporate leverage with
worryingly rising delinquencies and of course expensive equity markets and falling profits. To
that extent these political events are a distraction from the main event, weak global economic
growth and perverse asset markets. So whilst the market preference for the status quo might be
celebrated in the short-term, actually when the fog clears all of the problems will still be there.

BE

(@Mo06: casual racism gets autodeleted.)

PM

Let’s take the UK for example. The market will most probably rally as it is doing today if Brexit
is rejected, but rally to where? We have already highlighted the excessive leverage and payout
ratios in the UK (see link,) but these are not the only problems. On a disaggregated basis,
median valuations are at the upper end of historical estimates (see below), profitability whether
measured on an ROE, ROA or ROIC basis has rarely been this weak outside of an economic
slump, and these figures do not materially change whether the problematic commodity and
financial sectors are included or not. Brexit or not, the UK equity market hardly looks healthy.

11:41 am
PM

David K did a Nuts post to this effect earlier

PM

http://ftalphavill...s-whens-the-crash/

PM

Let me get the SocGen chart

11:41 am
PM

undefined
BE

On Worldpay, heard nothing specific. Though volume's good.

11:42 am
Worldpay Group PLC (WPG:LSE): Last: 290.80, up 16.9 (+6.17%), High: 295.10, Low: 280.00, Volume: 4.49m
BE

There was a big Goldman payments conference last week, at which Worldpay presented.

BE

Worldpay CEO gave the opening address, in fact.

11:43 am
BE

It was all much as you'd expect, in terms of content.

BE

1) Collaboration between players in the payments ecosystem (banks,
telcos, retailers, tech vendors) is becoming an inevitable necessity as the
industry becomes more customer centric. Internet of Commerce is
emerging as a trend with wearables (fitness trackers, AR/VR eyewear,
clothing) and cars/ automotive needing to be payments enabled. 2)
Consolidation amongst payment processing vendors will continue given
potential for significant cost synergies. The future of the industry is
envisaged to be one of fewer, but more significant players across verticals
and geographies. 3) Omni-commerce continues to gain traction, blurring
the lines between offline and online. As the core processing function gets
commoditized, tech platform differentiation remains key and vendors have
to enhance their capabilities beyond traditional functions into value added
services augmented by data analytics. 4) Regulatory changes are
expected to be a net incremental positive for tech vendors. PSD2 is the
next major initiative in Europe, which likely has implications to the existing
rails but could take time to implement. 5) Security continues to be in
focus with an emphasis on software-based solutions (HCE, tokenisation) as
fraud continues to proliferate broadly. 6) Emerging Markets provide a
greenfield opportunity given increasing proliferation of electronic
payments across EM geographies, both as a function of growth in the
middle classes and also due to the "war on cash" pursued by governments.
Inclusiveness of unbanked population into the payment value chain
continues at a rapid pace. 7) Blockchain could be a disruptive threat to the
existing payments rails, but is unlikely to have an impact in the next
decade. 8) VC spending in fintech is currently focused on online insurance
broking, P2P lending, crowdfunding and other technologies driving
efficiencies in traditional financial services. Blockchain remains an area
with significant scope for additional investments.

BE

\o/ Blockchain! \o/

11:44 am
BE

Let's get excited about databases again, like it's 1972.

BE

But, no, will ask around but nothing currently.

undefined
11:45 am
BE

(@Rushian: will see what we can do.)

PM

Sheesh, Liberum are sticking to their guns on Pearson

PM

Reiterate as our top Sell in media.

11:45 am
BE

(@fjp73: From whom? Haven't seen anything today.)

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 856.50, up 33.5 (+4.07%), High: 856.50, Low: 841.50, Volume: 790.58k
BE

This is on the CMD, right?

11:46 am
PM

Yeah, on Friday

PM

Ian Whittaker wasnt impressued

PM

But he's a lonely voice on this one now

11:47 am
PM

Reminder: we closed our virtual short when Fallon promised to maintain the 6.5% yield

PM

Anyway, Liberum

PM

Not much new from Pearson’s investor day

Pearson’s investor day, as expected, delivering not much particularly new – there was a reiteration of its optimism about meeting its targets (FY16E adjusted EPS of 50p-55p / adjusted operating profit target of £580m-620m and FY18E adjusted operating profit target of £800m); that its problems in US Higher Education are cyclical in nature and related to enrolment weakness; and talk about how the company is tapping into the new opportunities such as Online Programme Management in the US. Essentially, it was a padded out version of what the management stated at its strategic update call and FY results presentation earlier this year with a number of product demonstrations thrown into the mix.

11:47 am
PM

Pearson gave its view on where it thinks Higher Education will go

It was clear from the presentation that Pearson is grappling hard with the changes it faces: much was made of how Higher Education is changing and the challenges that it brings for HE institutions, and how Pearson can be a trusted partner handling the whole of support from enrolment, course design and, of course, materials: in effect, Pearson’s ideal model would be to have the institutions pay the materials as part of a bundled service, with student fees including the cost of these materials. There was also discussion of how digital will transform Higher Education and the implications for Pearson’s model.

PM

Little in here to address the structural concerns over Higher Education

Our biggest concern on Pearson has always been in US Higher Education and that students essentially are moving away from buying expensive textbooks and course material, which are very high margin for Pearson, as other alternatives (book rentals, Open Education Resources etc) start to appear. However, Pearson really did not address that: its forecasts of 0-2% US Higher Education revenue growth (which it claimed could be in a range of mid-single digit declines to high single digit-growth depending on cyclical factors) only assumed a modest impact from book rentals (where the publishers have been claiming for several years will lose momentum but have not done so far) and Open Education Resources, which seems optimistic given price differentials. On the new services, the history of MOOCs (hype, predictions of rapid and transformational growth and then disappointment) should act as a warning to expect too much benefit from universities transforming, particularly as the Online Programme Management market is competitive.

PM

Hard to see how Pearson can give guidance when visibility is low

It is also difficult to see how management could be so confident on guidance. US Higher Education peer J Wiley (NR) stated on their call last week that it is difficult to give longer-term operating margin guidance because print trends are unpredictable (it pointed out FY16 print performance was worse than expected) and that from what they are seeing now, print declines unlikely to improve much for the crucial Autumn season (-23% yoy in Q4). That raises questions over both Pearson’s FY16 guidance and how Pearson can predict £800m adjusted operating profit for FY18E.

11:48 am
PM

Market can remain insane longer than you might be solvent.... etc

BE

On the flipside to all that, David Reynolds at Jefferies enjoyed getting out of the office.

BE

Taurel, Fallon, Williams, on fine form. Second time we have seen the senior
management team in action, more and more impressive, coherent, forward thinking and
very focused. Bozik, Hitchcock. But perhaps even more impressive, Tim Bozik, President
Global Product and Albert Hitchcock, Chief Technology and Operations Officer seemed like
the kind of practioners any global technology company would covet, and, in our opinion,
clearly making a difference.

11:49 am
BE

Tim Bozik and Product, a quiet revolution. Didn't get that much from the formal
presentations, a tad too American and laden with opaque technical language. But having
a play with the 'integrated digital' product REVEL, intrigued to learn that it has been built
on PSON IP, technology partner Knewton not involved and it looked pretty good. Talking it
through with Tim Bozik, there seemed to be, dare we say, a certain revolutionary dynamic
at play, talk of leveraging PSON's scale advantage by capitalising on data-driven insight for
students, educators and PSON. Early days clearly, but the intent clear and if the starting point is a c.60% market share in US HE digital courseware, the opportunity PSON's to lose here.

BE

.... "a tad too American and laden with opaque technical language" ......

BE

Nope. Can't imagine that of Pearson.

11:49 am
BE

Albert Hitchcock and Technology, real progress. The scale of the technology
challenge evidences PSON's past mistakes, but the operational, competitive and financial
upside on offer, should Hitchcock succeed in simplifying and advancing PSON's core
technology infrastructure (be that in ERP, CRM or content management) is enormous. More
pragmatically, we learned that some 3,200 FTE's had thus far gone and the drive to simplicity
is on track. The combination of Hitchcock and Williams driving this diverse and complex
initiative hard is impactful, and we suspect will bring material benefits to PSON.
Risks remain, can PSON be radical enough? Higher Education has been, is and will
be, the key to PSON delivering competitively and thereafter financially. Be it in the US or
China, the HE world is in distress and ripe for digital and broader disruption. Enjoyed the
fireside chat with Ed Byrne, Kings College London, but that felt too safe. Thought struck us
that PSON possibly remain blind-sided by the potentially radical competitive threat. Whether
that is Google et al seeking degree awarding authority, the rise of digital educational
programmes and perhaps the inevitable inability of traditional academia to transform.

PM

Do you think Fallon got the analysts involved in a scavenger hunt and got them to wear coloured head scarfs?

BE

?

11:50 am
PM

Cos that's what he likes to do with the senior exec team

PM

wink smile

BE

Really. Cripes.

11:51 am
PM

Yes, really

BE

I'm not sure if that's better or worse than the Chinese approach.

undefined
11:51 am
PM

Ah, just got a new poll out

PM

Shocking really, this one

BE

Hooray! Never enough polls.

11:51 am
PM

UK’s drivers and white van man overwhelmingly do not trust the EU on motoring issues related to roads, emissions, safety standards, fuel tax, cost of motoring or car manufacturing issues.

PM

This is the FairFuelUK Campaign

BE

The what?

11:52 am
PM

We i guess has been dormant of late

BE

What's unfair about fuel?

PM

Respondents were asked: ‘Are you getting reliable well balanced evidence from both sides of the EU argument to make an informed decision on June 23rd?’: 66.2% said NO with only 1 in 8 saying YES.

The full survey results show the responses towards these motoring issues listed below and how being in or out of the EU will benefit or hinder them.

What’s best for vehicles exports manufacturing prices – on 4 related questions: Vote Leave responses range from 52% to 70.3%. Vote Remain responses range from 12% to 21.6%

What’s best for environment emissions safety – on 6 related questions: Vote Leave responses range from 42.9% to 57.9%. Vote Remain responses range from 9.9% to 19.8%

What’s best for roads transport potholes - on 3 related questions: Vote Leave responses range from 71.3% to 73.2%. Vote Remain responses range from 5.0% to 8.5%

What’s best for tax VAT Fuel Prices / cost of motoring - on 6 related questions: Vote Leave responses range from 63.1% to 74.9%. Vote Remain responses range from 4.7% to 15.7%

​What’s best for the Haulage Industry? Vote Leave response = 69.2% and Vote Remain response = 15%

11:57 am
BE

Inmarsat has fallen -34% in sterling (TSR) over the last six months. We believe this is overdone and was partly, at least, due to the compounding of having its principal market (Maritime) going into a severe recession just as Inmarsat commenced its product migration to GlobalXpress (GX), coinciding with management deciding to advance the capex cycle for its next generation of satellites. From here we believe the benefits of its investments will become more apparent as more resellers and end-customers sign for GlobalXpress in maritime and as it achieves type approvals in civil aviation and starts to see more airline orders. Being dollar earning it also provides insulation against the risk of sterling weakness should the UK vote to leave the EU. We upgrade to Buy and raise our target price to £9.00 from £8.80 due to the new £/$ exchange rate.

BE

Inmarsat has recently announced that the largest and fourth largest maritime communications resellers have committed to GX: over the next five years Marlink has signed for over 2,000 vessels and Speedcast for around 2,000. In size these compare to 2,633 XpressLink customers which Inmarsat serves directly, generating around $100m in annual revenue and set to migrate to GX over the next 18 months. We expect the yields on the reseller served vessels to be lower than XpressLink due to wholesale discounts and taking into account falling prices for bandwidth over time impacting the later contract years.

BE

GlobalXpress is available commercially now in Inmarsat’s Government, Maritime and Enterprise markets. We expect an important milestone in 3Q16 with commercialisation of the aviation offer. GX needs aircraft type and sub type approval by the industry and the civil aviation authorities and waiting for this might in our view be holding back some airlines from signing up for service. We also expect the company to upgrade long term guidance for the fourth GX satellite at some stage, although we do expect the assumed yields to be lower than those implied by the $500m target for the first three.
